724760f-b.title: Manhattan: White Street - South Street
724760f-b.text:
(1)
Whitehall Street, at, adjoining and north of the N.E. corner of South
Street. Also shown is South Street, at the N.E. corner of Whitehall
Street.
October 10, 1932.
P. L. Sperr.
NO REPRODUCTIOS.
(2)
An earlier view of the corner building which was the former Eastern
Hotel and known as such, since 1856. The original building was erected
prior to 1790, when it was purchased by John B. Coles for 350 pounds.
In 1822 it became the Eagle Hotel, a tavern. Much of the frame work is
solid mahogany, having been imported as ballast by the original owner, a
sea captain. At the time of purchase by Coles, who used it as a warehouse,
it was 3-stories high.
October 1923.
Eugene L. Armbruster Collection.
MAY BE REPRODUCED.

723226f-a.text:
South Street, north side, from Whitehall to Moore
Street's (left to rightl, showing buildings at this
extremity. The South Ferry ''El station at the Bat-
tery is at the left margin. Views 2 \& 3 are limited
to the structures at Moore Street. 0verhead in the
last item are several Goodyear Co. blimps according
to the photographer.

723224f-b.title: Manhattan: South Street - Whitehall Street
723224f-b.text:
South Street, east of Whitehall Street, as photographed
from the South Ferry ''El' station platform. On the right are
the various East River piers. Note the early sailing vessels.
On the left is the Eastern Hotelg and known as such since 1856.
The original building was erected prior to 1790, when it was
purchased by John B. Coles for 350 pounds. In 1822 it became
the Eagle Hotel, a tavern. Much of the freme work is solid
mahogany, having been imported as ballast by the original owner,
a sea captain. At the time of purchase by Coles, who used it
as a warehouse, it was 3 stories in height.
1893
E2: Sept. 1927
J. S. Johnston, photo
Gift of the Seamen's Church Institute
CREDIT LINE IMPERATIVE
George L. Balgue, photo
MAY BE REPRODUCED

724759f-a.title: Manhattan: White Street - South Street
724759f-a.text:
Whitehall Street, north from South Street (right, not
shown). This locale is known as South herry (the photo-
graphers vantage point), and Battery Park and State St.
are on the left. In the center is the old Produce Ex-
change between Water and Pearl Street's. This site was
latter improved with the formidable Army Building. Across
the roof appears the spire of Trinity Church, while to
the right is that atop St. Pauls Chapel.
186'Os
Gift of Urbrock Collection
HAY BE REPRODUCED
724759f-a.folder: White Street & South Street, Manhattan, NY
